description: The length of time the customer has been with the company, as longer-tenured customers may be less likely to churn.
The number of customer support interactions, as customers who have had multiple interactions may be more likely to churn due to unresolved issues.
How often the customer uses the product or service, as lower usage frequency may indicate a higher likelihood of churn.
The customer's history of on-time payments, as those with a consistent payment history may be less likely to churn.
The presence of competitive offers or promotions from other companies, as these may influence a customer's decision to churn.
Sentiment analysis of customer feedback and interactions, as negative sentiment may indicate a higher likelihood of churn.
The length of the customer's contract, as those with shorter contract lengths may be more likely to churn.
The extent to which the customer engages with specific product features, as low engagement may indicate a higher likelihood of churn.
Changes in the customer's demographic information, such as address or marital status, as these changes may influence churn behavior.
The customer's engagement with marketing campaigns, as higher engagement may indicate a lower likelihood of churn.
Whether the customer is part of a loyalty program, as this may influence their decision to stay with the company.
How the customer has reacted to past price changes, as negative reactions may indicate a higher likelihood of churn.
The customer's engagement with new product updates or releases, as low engagement may indicate a higher likelihood of churn.
Feedback on the user experience of the product or service, as poor user experience may lead to higher churn rates.
The customer's presence and activity on social media, as this may influence their loyalty to the company.
Success of cross-selling efforts, as customers who have engaged with additional products may be less likely to churn.
Life events such as marriage, new job, or retirement, as these events may trigger churn behavior.
The level of trust and satisfaction the customer has with the company, as this may impact their decision to stay or leave.
The customer's engagement with the company's community or forums, as active participation may indicate lower churn likelihood.
The extent to which the customer uses different products or services offered by the company, as higher variety usage may indicate lower churn likelihood.
Patterns of app usage, such as time of day and frequency, as this may indicate user engagement and potential churn risk.
Scores from customer feedback surveys, as low scores may indicate dissatisfaction and potential churn risk.
Preferences for communication channels (e.g., email, phone, chat), as aligning with preferences may reduce churn risk.
The availability of the product or service in the customer's location, as limited availability may increase churn risk.
The average time taken to resolve customer complaints, as longer resolution times may increase churn risk.
History of changes to the customer's subscription plan, as frequent changes may indicate potential churn risk.
The customer's history of relationship with the company, including any past churn events and re-engagement, as this may indicate likelihood of future churn.
Changes in economic indicators (e.g., unemployment rate, inflation) that may impact customer's financial situation and churn likelihood.
The influence of friends, family, or social circles on the customer's decision to stay or leave the service, as social influence can impact churn behavior.
The education level of the customer, as it may correlate with churn behavior due to different financial and lifestyle factors.
